txt: No need for more housing in Upper Falls village center. Northland will meet that need.
If you so idealize Somerville, why did you chose to live in Newton?  Don’t insist on changing Newton - try moving to Somerville.
More short term parking is needed in some villages. Some already have more than they need.
Village centers should offer space to car-sharing services like Zipcar
Buildings in the village centers should not be higher than 2-4 stories.
Intersection of Chestnut Washington & Watertown St is a nightmare. Why no R turn onto Watertown St? Why build out that section of sidewalk?
Newton is not welcoming to low-income people
My village center needs more useful everyday shops like a grocery, hardware, clothing, and shoe stores.
I think that Newton’s stores are doing a good job at looking inclusive, and keeping storefronts low to the sidewalk and accessible.
We are building transit-oriented devpt where there is little transit. Roads will become very clogged. Transit should become a priority
We need more places to have fun and meet people
New developments are empty because prices are too high and transit is insufficient to reduce need for cars.
Newton's current leadership is not transparent.
Newton should make the process easier to build affordable housing by either non-profit or private developers -- whatever it takes to do it.
With almost 250 new housing units - Trio, 77 Court St, 28 Austin, Newtonville has done its share to create housing with big developments.
People should walk or bike more to local stores and village centers and avoid using the car (even if convenient and quicker)
There should be public spaces which can be enjoyed without buying anything
New developments should have courtyard type footprints with small business storefronts. The parking lot at Trio in Newtonville lacks this
We should add density evenly throughout the city, since only the Green Line has reliable, frequent transit.
What most hurts quality of life in our village is ubiquitous gas-powered leaf blowers. Why have outdoor space if conversation is impossible?
A center of commerce and social activity for a village. Businesses that draw browsing and foot traffic, so more retail/dining vs. offices.
Adequate parking is very important
West Newton and Auburndale are not valued by stakeholders as much as other villages in Newton.
Quality affordable housing must be built for seniors and low income residents in and around transit hubs and village centers.
i wish my village center had more reliable transit
New places for people to live should be in or near villages and transit. Better for our climate, our local businesses & building community.
Keep the outdoor eating bump-outs and try to create more.  Very festive and draws patrons.
I like driving around to the various village centers to do my errands.
Zhen Li
Frequent Commuter Rail and  express buses to Boston are critical to minimizing traffic and improving air quality. Save 505 bus.
I now do most shopping via e-commerce but village centers are still important for me for day-to-day tasks.
I wish there was a bookstore in my village center.
Increasing density in village centers will increase walkability and encourage people to do more trips without their cars.
Creating a transit oriented development does not make sense if the residents have to take a shuttle to get to public transportation.
Accessible Green Roofs are a good way to increase green space and climate resiliency
To really address climate change, we need more and smarter transit--both into the city and for the last mile.
We need more rental options in newton
Allow extended parking everywhere but for an exponentially increasing fee: 1st hour free, 2nd hour $10, additional hours $20
Large, new developments should be 25% affordable to qualify all units on SHI to gain and retain safe harbor from 40B law.
Most of these statements seem to have a bias toward crowding village centers.
only allow newton residences to park for more then 4 hours. eliminate out of towns using us as a spot to drive to jump on public transit
Priority should be given to increasing frequency of commuter rail service along Washington st corridor to service planned buildings
The new streets/bike lanes on West Newton are confusing and nonsensical. They start and stop, and the streetlights are super confusing.
There are areas in Newton which are already to congested    New development should occur in the less densely populated areas.
Cars + e-shopping mean village centers will never again be places people HAVE to use. They’ll only survive if people WANT to use them.
The Mayor should advocate, w/ Brookline & Wellesley, for express Bus/E-mobility lanes on Rt. 9, & partner w bike shops to subsidize e-bikes.
With many new apts coming on board ie Northland, Wash st it is hard to consider adding density without first feeling the effects of those
I think most of these questions are leading, and the author is trying to get predetermined answers
Our village centers would benefit from more multi-family housing on top of retail.
Build parking garages off the center: In Newton Center: behind Walgreens, over the green line or the on the Fire Department building.
I go to village centers in order to have a good time with friends and "hangout"
Newton is racially segregated. Desegregation will only occur if we act intentionally.
I rent my residence.
Allowing more housing near villages and transit will NOT turn Newton into Brookline, Cambridge or Somerville.
village centers should have public indoor spaces in addition to parks, etc
Build the T line to Needham parallel to Needham Street, as originally planned.
Newton should strongly prefer ownership over renting. Condos more than rental apartments.
I live in a condo or apartment.
We need traffic circles in N Highlands: at the corner of Walnut@Lincoln, Lincoln@Woodward.
I moved to newton for what it was, don’t try to radically change it
Why is the city repeating the same format that created the form based zoning.  It is a failed process.
Change focus from housing to transit to get cars off streets.  If transit is available, housing will come.
We need to be able to build accessible,smaller apartments throughout the city--not just in village centers
Village centers should be kept distinct and not merge into each other on Washington St.
I don't think this survey is representative of all Newton residents.
How about a bike path thru the woods adjancent to Hammond Pond Parkway all the way to Skyline Park in Brookline?   Maybe farther to Mt. Ida?
The writer(s) saying cut up “mansions” and Victorians into multi units are being arrogant, jealous virtue signaler. Not constructive
building middle income housing in wealthy communities prevents middle income people from gentrifying other neighborhoods & we should do that
Making a center hostile to cars will not stop the usage, it will only increase congestion, danger to pedestrians, and general confusion.
There is a healthy mix of types of businesses in a village center, and the city should establish zoning guidelines to promote this.
We need public transportation between West Newton Square and Woodland T station/Newton Wellesley Hospital
Speed bumps are not necessary through village centers
We need multi-unit housing in and near the village centers. Preferably by right.
I feel unsafe in my village center as a pedestrian
Farmers markets are greatly underutilized as community events. (Chicago is a great example of how to do it right…more like a festival!)
village centers should have spaces for music performances
I do not do many of my errands in my village center because there are no basic businesses.  I do go to the post office & CVS.
The north side of Newton should not bear the brunt of all new development
I believe the health of businesses in village centers is tied to its adjoining base of customers.
There is too much traffic.
As a matter of equity and community responsibility, increases in housing density should be equal in high- and low-density areas.
ZAP members are virtue signaling social engineers.  Homeowners bought here & not Brookline/Cambridge/Somerville for good reason. Cut it out!
Food and coffee are needs of all people. So good to have in an Upper Falls village center.
3-4 story mixed use buildings in VCs would keep our village economies strong, provide needed housing in walkable locations, build community.
simply cut village center business taxes to help business survive- don’t add density
Build a first class bicycle highway on Commonwealth Ave Carriageway
I think it is not realistic to not expect folks to drive their cars.  We need parking in the village centers so we can support local.
The current mix of businesses in the village centers is good for the community.
Walkability is key to the sense of village center, the more traffic/cars involved, the less walkable it will be.
Non-white people were intentionally excluded from Newton. We need to be active to change Newton's demographics.
N'ville and W.N. aren't transit-oriented according to US' premier T-O Dev. institute - long intervals, infrequent service.  Green Line is.
Newton Corner needs a complete reimagining to be safe (for pedestrians/cyclists/cars), vibrant (with varied businesses) and welcoming
introduce technology to make paying for paring seamless
There are currently more bike lanes than people willing to use them.
Build dedicated bike “boulevards” that connect village centers, schools, parks and the T stations.
Village center zoning should allow for mixed-use buildings of 4-5 stories in order to accommodate retail, apartments and commercial space.
If the city could somehow  acquire  Santander property in Newton Centre, that would be an ideal location for a small (24 unit) apt building
The mix of retail in Newton Centre is odd. Example: There are 3 places to get  luggage repaired. I have never in my life repaired luggage
This city and all of its villages are way too white.
To have local and small businesses Landlords need a tax break to rent to them.
Frequent Shuttle bus from west Newton to Newton corner bus stops servicing new developments
I live in Newtonville, but visit village centers that offer what I need. Nonantum, then Newton Center, West Newton, and Newtonville is last.
This is not a valid statement.  The number of stories in a building in a village center is entirely dependent on context.
i feel unsafe in my village center as a biker
I own my house.
Older adults (like me) need apt. bldgs. near village centers – small, but big enough for elevators (12-24 units?) -- so we can drive less.
We bought near a village center because of walkability and that seems to no longer be a priority
Our aging population will not bike to village centers during our unpredictable weather to visit the seventeen banks that operate there.
Allow more housing above stores in our villages.
I am increasingly doing my errands in Watertown & Waltham because I can park my car easily & for free.
The town seems determined to add density regardless of whether it will realistically add affordable housing or not
This polis is pseudo-science.  Newton is investing time, money and energy in this malarkey. Why not do a scientific survey?
large/dense developments should include community benefits agreements negotiated with neighborhood stakeholders
The changes to centers will make annual festivals in which streets are closed off (parade, Village days) more difficult due to lack of space
We have a moral obligation to create affordable housing opportunities, especially for historically marginalized communities.
Buildings are 64% of GHG emissions by Newton's own measurements. We need efficient buildings - several smaller living spaces under one roof
Traffic is horrible and getting worse.
Build dedicated bicycle superhighways: next to D line in the Nahanton Woods, over the Sudburry Aqueduct, over the Upper-Falls Greenway
This strange and undisciplined process raises big questions about ZAP's competency to manage & expedite any realistic zoning modifications.
There should be more rotaries/roundabouts in Newton to improve safety and reduce traffic
It is rediculous that the center of Newton Centre is a parking lot. That space needs to be reimagined. Add low rise garages on lots
There should be a tapering effect as you approach a village center, buildings should get taller as they get closer to transit
Allow 2-3 rd floor office space at reduced tax rate ( maybe zero) to increase number folks in village centers during day early evening
Has Newton become a socialist state?
I think the city ( mayor, council, planning dept) already has a plan of what they are  Going to do, and are just using this as cover
Easy parking at village centers is more important to me than the walking and biking experience.
The small types of businesses that can thrive in village centers need lower taxes and rent.
There are going to be significant neg impacts to my village from Northland.
All day Commuter Rail and reasonable hours for express buses to Boston are critical to minimize traffic and improve air quality.
The City isn’t addressing  RAT prblms TRIO and Sunrise created.  Public health hazard. Will it do better (NOT) with more “densification”?
Officially-affordable1-BR  apts. at Trio rented for $2475/mo last December.  This was $700/mo.  more than 1-BR naturally affordable apts.
So Newton is expensive.  Weston, Wellesley and Dover are too. Do I have a “moral right” to live there if I can’t afford it?  Don’t think so…
My local village center is important to my neighborhood’s sense of community.
Newton is trending to be over developed
It would be awesome to have each village center be fully pedestrian. This could be achieved with careful and creative traffic planning
3, 4 and 5 story buildings help create a sense of place in village centers and aligns with what the city had historically.
Character of adjacent lower density historic neighborhoods eg those on National Register of Historic places should be preserved/improved.
Near village centers, we should allow small multifamily bldgs. that can’t be “mansionized” and that let families get by with just one car.
Everyone can travel 10-20 minutes, better live in quiet safe place
More housing (ie. people) will help us keep the local shops we love thriving in our village center.
There should be more public green space along Washington Street and in the village centers
Public parking policies in village centers should prioritize shorter trips for patronizing businesses
The number of banks per village center should be capped.
How will 50-80% AMI affordable housing support VC businesses? Those folks have limited disposable income to spend at those stores
Expand sidewalks, increase and beautify outdoor dining / cafe space.
If there was a co-working space in a nearby village center, I would be interested in using it on occasion rather than working from home.
I visit businesses in the village center closest to where I live the most often.
This survey's respondents are a self-selecting, unrepresentative sample which mitigates against generalizing with scientific confidence.
All Village Centers and Historic Districts should be made free of ugly utility poles and cables by Ordinance -to be done by corp. owners.
Too much Government involvement.
There is no reason to concentrate development in the village centers.  Most northside villages lack reliable transit.
We need to be able to build accessible, smaller apartments near transit/village centers (12 units is minimum for elevator buildings)
Newton’s a bedroom community, adding more bedrooms won’t help village business where it’s needed most- daytime.
It is possible to honor history and also change things to make them better
Four Corners has a lot of potential to become a more walkable neighborhood if there were more places to live right in that area.
We need to include renewable energy technology and accessibility modifications for disabled people in our village center buildings.
Adequate, but expensive parking off the village centers is important. We should not use the middle of the centers for parking.
During construction, pedestrians need dedicated space when sidewalks are blocked; people are forced to walk in the street currently
I rarely, if ever see bicyclists using bicycle lanes.
The only thing that might attract me to my village center is interesting (non-chain) restaurants with adequate, safe parking.
More outdoor seating, dining, meeting places. COVID has taught us that we can (and like to) hang out outdoors.
Village Centers should be destinations with specialty stores, small businesses, restaurants, and arts organizations that attract people
I believe that Newton is a suburb.
To really address climate change, Newton needs to allow more places to live near the T and train - less driving, fewer cars.
Newton needs to make it possible for people to live without cars.
We need to find ways for people who don't live near village centers to contribute to helping with climate change.
When roads are updated, signs need to follow. After the West Newton reconfiguration in Jan '21, signage had not been updated as of June '21
Polis has 17,000+ votes by ~200 people. (Some “people” are duplicates on multi devices) How does this reflect Newton’s 86,000 residents? NOT
The Newton Highlands building shd have more floors/units due to the proximity to the subway, which is a great way to commute into Boston.
It needs to be easier to get to the west newton commuter rail station
Village centers should have high density parking areas eg multi-floored, maybe on the margins of the centers, so they take up less space
Zoning question should be on ballot in election so that vocal few don’t over shadow the voters of newton
We need more bike racks in Village Centers and by T stations.
Each village center will have a space for cultural & community events that can be used by all.
3-4 story blgs a in VCs is a major change/bad idea. It only takes a few taller buildings to make a canyon. NO MORE TRIO HULKS
Zoning by tweet (140 characters) doesn’t foster communication AMONG residents.
I live near a village center and worry that high rises will overwhelm my small property
Our quiet neighborhood is destined to be overshadowed by luxury condos
I think it's important for the local stores and restaurants  in villages to have enough people living nearby to support their businesses.
The only way to reduce traffic congestion is to increase street size, not decrease it. Decreasing bottlenecks the whole center.
zoning near village centers should increase feasibility for projects over the pike which increase north/south connectivity
Upper Falls village center is hard to walk &!bike to as sidewalks aren’t good and no bike lanes. Parking not good either so limits customers
The public transit in my neighborhood does not meet my needs.
Bigger density will create more problems, then advantages - we have everything in 10 minutes from us, having it in 2 minutes doesn't not pay
I am a homeowner who purchased in Newton with expectations of stability that densification would destroy.
Villages need to be accessible from OUTSIDE to people with disabilities, not only within - otherwise how will we even get there?
The character limit in these boxes should be increased so we can convey more complete thoughts/concepts
Newton needs more homes or condos or apartments that are smaller so they will be less expensive.
Auburndale Village needs improvement so it can be more walkable and better serve as a safe and attractive gathering place for the residents.
We are relying too much on the commuter rail when we are planning Washington St.
improve public transportation throughout the city, not just village centers.
Limit number of banks, there are over 9 in Newton Center. Limit single use bank building like BofA in Newton Center.
Private developers seek profit & ROI. It’s natural. They INCREASE housing costs.  ZAP’s “densification” dance makes Newton more expensive.
I now do most shopping via e-commerce but village centers are still important for `me for day-to-day tasks.
Decrease larger lot sizes to allow for more green space in crowded village centers and along Washington Street.
To build more affordable housing, Newton should rely more on housing developments by non-profit community organizations.
I dislike feeling like I have to drive everywhere because of the lack of bike lanes.
It is good to know what people want in their village in the future but also specifics about what they wish to preserve (by village).
The city should do more to slow (calm) traffic down as most motorists do not observe traffic speeds (even during rush hours).
We need free, public transportation to connect Newton’s Village Centers
I think it would be helpful to understand how many residents define Newton as suburban vs urban, why and which they prefer. Core discussion!
I do not want to lose the feel of Newton - which is a blend of village centers and neighborhoods
I shop in other places
There should be frequent bus service to connect the villages of Newton.
We need more bike lanes that go all the way to Village Centers.
The changes in Newtonville make it impossible to drive through. The Walnut/Washington intersection is downright dangerous now.
Funding for building vibrant accessible, culture-rich village centers should be reallocated from the police budget
denser housing in VC not a panacea.  Add more density throughout the city and provide accessible transportation to centers & MBTA
Should have groups of mini stores fronts that would be affordable for small businesses or crafts people. Retail rents are too high for many
I would prefer to have taxes go to supporting city services rather than subsidies for commercial landlords
Who is filtering the comments for community reaction on this polis? I’ve submitted a series of comments but never see them come up for votes
To balance development geographically, allow detached accessory apts., by right, respecting setbacks, in the less dense parts of Newton.
Depends on the business
Buildings in or right next to villages could be 3-4 stories if they include housing to make the villages more walkable and vibrant.
We moved out of Cambridge for a reason. Please don’t try to turn Newton into another Cambridge
Newton needs to build these apartment buildings near the subway stops which run frequently & the cost is reasonable.
The Washington st redevelopment plan should give lanes/space to the commuter rail station to make construction & use easier.
The Framingham line should be electrified
I want my VC to be walkable and sociable, with PO, bank,  neighbors, and where small businesses I love can thrive.
If want to attract more business to village center then streamline process at city hall to make more business friendly and cost effective
We have too many mansions. Some should be split into multifamily housing.
Single-story buildings in village centers do not add enough vibrancy to the environment. We need more with 3, 4, or 5 stories.
The new benches in Newtonville are nice but misplaced. They are too far apart for people to hang out
I'd like to see housing added above retail in the Village Centers
Community events should include newton residents, those who work in schools and those who have children in the school system.
More benches scattered around the village center. (pocket parks perhaps)
I like eating outside with my family, at a restaurant but also picnic style
The renovations to village centers that have aspired to increase walking and bikeing have slowed bike traffic due to the high car traffic
Not everyone can afford a down payment so there should be more rental opportunities near village centers
Newton has found ways to have community gatherings without completely closing off centers to outside traffic and businesses
Use our high school artists to design and paint murals on everything from alleys to unsightly electrical boxes.
Incentives to some businesses like free standing banks (i.e Santander in NC) to relocate so the property can be better utilized better
The Auburndale center roadway redesign introduced new safety issues by making Comm Ave parking spaces too narrow for trucks
Using multiple devices to respond, records as multiple people on polis.  Polis is unscientific/useless to measure public opinion accurately
Four stories is really not that high.
It is NOT time (yet) to make driving to our village centers anything but convenient.
Large developments have decreased adjacent property values and cause traffic problems throughout the city.
City leadership ( mayor and city council) are out of touch with the community
villages become more dense (urban) allows Newton to have the best of urban and suburban, urban in the center, with sub-urban not far away.
We are planning again but still do not know what will result from all the time and energy spent on the Washington Street Corridor process,
Our group thought about implementing car charging ports at the various parking lots.
We can't welcoming, safe, vibrant village centers many want and at the same time maximize car throughput and speed through them.
“Zoning Redesign” is totally the wrong tool for promoting ZAP’s/Albright’s/Filler’s social agenda. That’s done by economic policy.
A vibrant, walkable village center is an attractive amenity that INCREASES home values.
Put more traffic circles: On Beacon street at Hammond Pond Pkws, at Langley Rd, at Center Street, at Walnut street, at Waban and at the end
Many people commenting on densifying the village centers should realize by doing so their village centers will become urban centers.
More density will make it even less safe
Bring back the trees in Newton. And start with the areas where the canopy is the less dense now = green wisdom and social justice.
Allowing denser retail, commercial, education, and business in general will alleviate tax burdens on homeowners, like in other nearby cities
I like my village center, and shop there.
I wish there were smaller housing to own options in Newton!! I bought a house twice as big as what I wanted because that's what there was.
My village center needs more safe and inviting outdoor space to gather.
2 stories in VCs is plenty. More than that sacrifices character of a VILLAGE center. If I wanted urban, I’d have bought in Cambridge
We should look to the villages of countries like Italy for how to design a walkable, appealing, community center of gravity.
Commuter rail tracks in village centers should provide subway-type service (e.g., 10 min peak service) connecting to the broader T network
I want to be able to safely bike with my grandchildren in Newton.
Outdoor dining brings vibrancy to village centers
More public green spaces -- parks, playgrounds on the north side of Newton.
I prefer a balanced, or shared approach to transport in Newton and our village centers (between cars, bikes and walking).
Newton is not a transit hub and now has fewer transit options than ever. So much development is planned around transit where there is none.
Village centers should promote community centered business: restaurants, discos, paint bars, escape rooms, performance places.
All traffic changes recently made make it extremely difficult to stop or drive through all affected centers
I think so many folks from outside newton drive here to get public transportation which create traffic and takes up parking
I care about my fellow men and women and i want to help those in need find a place to live - a village center would be a good place to live.
I am for a smaller development such as the proposal for 1149-1151 Walnut that is easily accessible to transit and contain smaller apts.
Avalon RE tax = $811K and school for Avalon kids = $1.386M- that’s a $575K loss BEfORE ANY other city services. STOP STUPID DEVELOPMENT
It's a lot of places around Newton with high density and lower prices. If we make Netwon the same it will be no variety, less choice.
We need public transit that goes from village to village.
Stop criticizing the people who own large, expensive houses. The hefty taxes they pay educate your children and fund City services.
Village Centers need a variety of boutique businesses, not just banks and nail salons.
We should believe the scientific consensus on climate change and plan for a sustainable future that is less car dependent
teardowns are happening under *current zoning* changes are needed for smarter development
The Framingham commuter rail stops in Newton should be rebuilt for convenient boarding in both directions.
Village Centers should have more areas for outdoor dining, socializing and lingering.
I think this whole issue of development in village centers should be a referendum question in election so voters can have a real say.
The village centers of Newton are more similar to each other than they are different.
it should be easier to get to the villages served by the green line from other villages without driving
I would like to see more housing in the villages but it needs to be aesthetically congruent with interesting architecture....not boxes
I don't think many people in the city even know what zone they live in.
Lots of cards, lots of opinions lots of vision, I want to see the summary of what people are saying!
Create outdoor performance spaces where student bands or other types of performers could set out their "compensation" boxes and perform!
Not every Village Center is treated the same by local government.
Heights of new residential developments in village centers should be 2 stories by right and 3 or 4 by Special Permit, as per current zoning
Consider staggered start times/additional periods for middle and high schools so students may use public transit and spread out car traffic.
Stop having fantasies of turning Newton into an old Italian walking town. We came here to live in the suburb, not in a town center.
I feel unsafe getting to my village center by bicycle.
On the suggestion to make Union Street a pedestrian mall: Ask the shopkeepers if they want that/how it would affect their businesses.
(For profit) developers of large projects should pay impact fees for the burdens they place on our schools and infrastructure, as in Boston.
Zoning should allow for denser development within 1/4 mi of transit, following Arlington VA's model: https://bit.ly/3yUj887 (PDF)
Village centers should have a center-- a public green space to congregate-- in the spirit of a European plaza.
Multifamily buildings should be easy to build near transit
I think the mayor is cuckoo for coco puffs
Students do bike tricks in traffic near the high schools are dangerous to all and should be fined
Instead of a pot shop, why can’t that property be made into multiple store fronts and allow access to the greenway?
The Washington Street plan is based on people using the commuter rail which does not run frequently & is expensive.
City leadership is out of touch with what residents want.
This survey is weak, as there are no standard definitions of terms, such as “more density” and “affordability.”
Cars are a reality. There needs to be parking for people to access the shops and amenities in our village centers.
New developments should be offset with adjacent street facing greenspace (trees, grass, plants)
Most of Newton would be untouched if there were more places to live near or in our villages and near transit.
Once I am in a Village Center, being able to easily and safely walk to all the businesses is important to me.
Newton needs more affordable housing for different income levels.
Housing should be part of our village centers.
Village Centers need to have residential (and office) space above retail, but also multi-family housing that is nearby, without retail.
Newton Centre is the de facto epicenter of Newton, to the neglect of other villages (they get all the festivals/community events).
Traffic in village centers and neighboring streets needs to be slowed down and intersection violations addressed, especially in West Newton
I Don’t feel obligated to create density in village centers. The burden of Density should be shared throughout the city.
If there was housing built in the parking lots of the Chestnut Hill Mall and near The Street the area could become a walkable community.
The automated 'No Turn on Red' sign at the Walnut/Washington intersection is unnecessary and an example of wasteful expenditure.
If not the entire space, we need spaces to retreat to (for kids during play, adults from shopping) for people with sensory disabilities.
The only way to reduce traffic congestion is to make not using one a viable alternative
Dismantle the school bus system and replace it with public bus system open to students and adults.
village centers should include an ice cream shop, a pizza place, and a place to sit and have coffee.
We need way more "affordable" and low income housing. The private marketplace provides very little of that . .  Government must invest.
City leadership is out of touch with Newton citizens
I want my village center to be a destination not a cut through
Build transit oriented, affordable senior housing + office space on the Newton Center parking lot
The push for densification will lower ever homeowner’s property values. I need my home equity to retire/live in old age. Who doesn’t?
Newtonville and West Newton are also in desperate need of decent public transportation. Buses and commuter train infrequent and often late
People who already own houses please stop gatekeeping homeownership for millenials. There's not enough houses at any size in boston area.
The city needs to prioritize people and mobility, especially for those on bike and on foot, above on-street parking.
A significant cause of today’s traffic is that housing and workplaces are as far apart as they have ever been, which increases commute times
Eliminate out of towners using newton as cut thru
OakHill/Newton Center/Memorial Spaulding neighborhood needs access to public transportation.
Zoning needs to accommodate updating and adding height to buildings in village centers.
I hope zoning rules will allow for commercial and multi-family housing. Housing could be constructed on 2d, 3d or 4th floors of buildings.
This will be the coldest summer of the rest of our lives. The idea that people can drive cars forever is a fantasy. We must adapt to CC.
Village centers are primarily for nearby residents rather than those coming from other centers or towns for work/shopping/dining
Another city made banks move to the second floor with only an ATM at street level to make more active storefronts. Seems like a good idea.
Rotaries/roundabouts are proven to be safer for cars and pedestrians than stoplights. They can also have green space in the center.
Young people/students should be able to afford a place to live near/around a village center in Newton.
We need sufficient housing within walking distance to support the village businesses we love and want to thrive
Landlords should be encouraged (perhaps a tax break?) to rent storefronts to smaller and independent businesses.
Each village 'center' should be able to have it's own idenity - therefore different zoning  / rules.
Rotaries/roundabouts help improve the walkability of village centers.
Village centers along the commuter rail need accessible ways to get to the tracks. It's overdue, considering ADA has been law for 31 years.
It should be easy, safe, and cheap to travel without a car (using public transportation, biking, walking, etc)
I like to stop in my village center on my way to/from work or school.
Shopping locally is neither affordable nor as convenient as shopping online; this will not change with more density and less parking
The Zoning & Planning Committee is currently redrafting building heights. Why is this happening without our “Vision”?
Resilience to extreme weather events from climate change is an important consideration in designing any changes to village centers
If we are going to have success building car-light housing in the Village Centers it is going to have to include public/private partnerships
It would be great for the environment/climate change and for local businesses if more people could live in or near village centers.
